research_goal.title: Novel Drug Repurposing for Acute Myeloid Leukemia
research_goal.description: Identify FDA-approved drugs that could be repurposed for acute myeloid leukemia (AML) treatment. Focus on drugs that can inhibit leukemic cell proliferation at clinically applicable concentrations, particularly targeting MOLM-13 cell lines.
constraints: Must have mechanism of action documentation
Focus on inhibiting AML cell proliferation

hypotheses.title: Hypothesis 1 (Literature-based): Biomedicine/Oncology Mechanism
hypotheses.description: Generated from synthesizing literature on Biomedicine/Oncology. This hypothesis proposes a novel mechanism integrating existing research.
hypotheses.mechanism: Building on current understanding of Biomedicine/Oncology, this mechanism suggests that the key pathway involves cross-disciplinary integration of molecular and systems-level effects.
testable_predictions: Prediction 1: Observable effect in Biomedicine/Oncology context
grounding_evidence: Wang et al. (2023) - Supporting pathway analysis

hypotheses.title: Hypothesis 2 (Assumption-based): Novel Target in Biomedicine/Oncology
hypotheses.description: Generated through systematic assumption identification in Biomedicine/Oncology.
hypotheses.mechanism: Logical chain: If assumption X holds → intermediate effect Y → final outcome Z

hypotheses.title: Hypothesis 3 (Analogy-based): Cross-domain Mechanism for Biomedicine/Oncology
hypotheses.description: Analogous to mechanisms in related domains, proposing novel application to Biomedicine/Oncology
hypotheses.mechanism: The mechanism discovered in Domain A may apply to Domain B through structural similarity

hypotheses.title: Hypothesis 4 (Unconventional): Divergent Mechanism in Biomedicine/Oncology
hypotheses.description: Explores unconventional directions in Biomedicine/Oncology research
hypotheses.mechanism: Moving away from established paradigms to explore underexplored mechanistic space
